metadata.title: Atomic indium decorated graphene for dendrite-free sodium anodes towards high-energy-density sodium-metal batteries

Graphical abstract The atomic indium-decorated graphene with high-valence In-O-C configuration and evenly distributed sodiophilic sites is designed to promote uniform nucleation and in-plane growth of Na on its surface, resulting in the intrinsic suppression of Na dendrites. Na metal batteries (SMBs) have emerged as a fascinating choice for large-scale energy storage. However, dendrite formation on Na metal anode has been acknowledged to cause inferior cycling stability and safety issues. Herein, we report the design of atomic indium-decorated graphene (In/G) to inhibit the growth of Na dendrites and substantially improve the stability of high-energy-density SMBs. Benefiting from the high-valence In-O-C configuration and evenly distributed sodiophilic sites, the In/G promotes uniform nucleation and in-plane growth of Na on the electrode surface, resulting in the intrinsic suppression of Na dendrites. Remarkably, the In/G@Na||Na batteries exhibit excellent long-term cyclability with 160 h at 8 mA cm−2 and ultralow overpotential of 110 mV at 10 mA cm−2. The Na3V2(PO4)3||In/G@Na full batteries show exceptionally high reversible discharge capacity of 61 mAh g−1 at an ultrahigh rate of 40 C and extremely low capacity decay rate of only 0.021% per cycle over 300 cycles at 1 C. Therefore, this strategy provides a new direction for the development of next-generation high-energy-density SMBs. Keywords Atomic indium decorated graphene Dendrite-free anode Sodium metal batteries High energy density 1 Introduction Sodium (Na) is abundant and widely distributed on earth compared to lithium (Li), positioning Na-ion batteries (SIBs) a highly cost-effective candidate for large-scale energy storage [1–5]. It is well known that the conventional graphite anode materials used in lithium-ion batteries exhibit poor performance when employed as the anode of SIBs due to the larger size of Na+ compared to Li+ [6,7]. Therefore, it is necessary to develop a high capacity anode for SIBs with long cycle life. Na metal has a very high theoretical capacity of 1165 mAh g−1 and a low redox potential of −2.71 V (versus the standard hydrogen potential), making Na metal batteries (SMBs) with Na metal as anode a promising type of SIBs [8–10]. However, Na metal anodes are facing many challenges akin to Li metal anodes. For instance, the severe reaction between Na metal and the organic liquid electrolyte can lead to the formation of a thick, non-uniform solid electrolyte interphase (SEI) film, which hinders uniform ion transport [11–13]. Further, the large volume change of Na metal anode during the repeated plating/stripping process can compromise the integrity of the SEI film and form dendritic Na, leading to low Coulombic efficiency (CE) and eventual depletion of the electrolyte [10,14,15]. On the other hand, the dendritic Na growth poses serious safety issues, such as puncture of the separator causing internal short circuit and eventually resulting in the battery explosion [16,17]. These challenges of poor cyclicity and safety concern are the primary factors that have greatly restricted the commercial application of SMBs. So far, three main strategies have been reported to improve the stability of Na metal anode. The first method is the surface modification of Na metal [8,18–20]. Representatively, plasma-enhanced atomic layer deposition has been employed to apply an Al2O3 layer on the surface of Na metal to prevent electrolyte decomposition and Na metal corrosion [18]. This process creates an artificial protective layer on Na metal by chemical or physical treatment, effectively inhibiting the excessive decomposition of electrolyte and dendritic Na growth. The second one is to design new electrode structures [9,21]. For instance, three-dimensional (3D) structures with high specific surface area have been constructed to host Na metal and subsequently accommodate the overall volume change of the electrode during electroplating/stripping. Typically, Sun et al. [9] used nitrogen and sulfur co-doped carbon nanotube paper as an intermediate layer to control the nucleation behavior of Na and inhibit the growth of Na dendrites. The third is to develop innovative solid-state electrolyte [22–24]. Inorganic ceramic electrolytes [23–25] or polymer electrolytes [22,26] with high mechanical strength can act as physical barriers to suppress the growth of Na dendrites. However, these methods have several shortcomings. It is difficult for surface modification strategy of Na metal to maintain mechanical stability towards large volume change in the case of high areal capacity. The presence of a large number of pores in 3D structure would cause the decline of volumetric energy density of SMBs. Moreover, the low ionic conductivity and large voltage polarization of solid-state electrolytes prevent their practical application in SMBs. Therefore, it is meaningful to develop new dendrite-free anode strategy to realize the uniform deposition of Na at high rate. Atomically dispersed materials possess uniform metallic sites, enabling the utmost utilization to guide metal deposition, which have been widely used for rechargeable batteries, such as Li metal and Li/Na-S batteries [27–31]. In this work, we report the designed construction of atomic In-decorated graphene (In/G) as a dendrite-free anode for high-energy and exceptionally stable SMBs. The introduction of atomic In intrinsically guarantees the uniform nucleation of Na and promotes its planar growth on the electrode surface. By regulating the high-valence In-O-C configuration and the evenly distributed sodiophilic sites between graphene layers, the dendritic growth of Na anode can be effectively prevented. As a result, the In/G@Na||Na cells show excellent long-term cyclability (160 h at 8 mA cm−2) and high rate capability (up to 10 mAh cm−2) and the half cells of In/G||Na show superior CE stability at 8 mA cm−2, indicative of significant suppression to the dendritic growth of Na metal. Furthermore, the Na3V2(PO4)3 (NVP)||In/G@Na full batteries offer high discharge capacity of 102 mAh g−1 at 1 C and high-rate capability of 61 mAh g−1 at an ultrahigh rate up to 40 C. 2 Results and discussion 2.1 Fabrication and characterization of atomic In/G The synthesis of atomic In/G is shown schematically in Fig. 1 (a). Typically, graphene oxide (GO) serves as the substrate, with In3+ ions being uniformly adsorbed due to the negative charge on the surface of GO. The atomic In/G materials are obtained through freeze-drying and self-propagating combustion in sequence. Scanning electron microscopy (SEM) image (Fig. S1) of In/G shows a nanosheet structure without any nanoparticles, and the elemental mapping images clearly demonstrate the homogeneous distribution of O, C, and In throughout the sheet, indicating the presence of In element. The X-ray diffraction (XRD) pattern of In/G (Fig. S2) reveals only two characteristic peaks of graphene [32], with no discernible peak for In2O3. Furthermore, transmission electron microscopy (TEM) and high-resolution TEM (HRTEM) images (Fig. 1b, c) prove the uniform dispersion of In element on graphene, without any aggregated In2O3 nanoparticles. The dispersion of In atoms on the graphene is further demonstrated by high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM) (Fig. 1d), where the highly dispersed isolated bright dots are attributed to individual In atoms, indicative of homogenously distributed In atoms on graphene. The chemical composition and elemental state of In/G are characterized using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The two peaks at 444.6 eV (In 3d 5/2) and 452.2 eV (In 3d 3/2) confirm the presence of In 3d in the In/G (Fig. 1e) [33–35], and the atomic In content in In/G materials is calculated to be 1.25 wt%. The O 1s XPS (Fig. S3a) can be deconvoluted into four peaks at the binding energy of 533.6, 533.0, 531.6, and 530.3 eV. The peak at 530.3 eV is assigned to the In–O bonding [34]. The peaks at 531.6 and 533.0 eV can be ascribed to C=O and C–OH functional groups on graphene surface [36]. The low-intensity broader peak at 533.6 eV is caused by the oxygen absorbed on the material surface [33]. The high-resolution C 1s spectrum (Fig. S3b) is deconvoluted into three peaks at 288.3, 285.1, and 284.1 eV, which are assigned to C=O, C–O, and C–C bonds, respectively [36–38]. These results indicate that the single In atoms are thoroughly dispersed on the graphene surface with the In-O-C configuration. To further confirm the chemical bond state of In element, we explored the local electronic structure and its interaction with the substrate by normalized X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectrum and extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS). The standard In2O3 was used for comparison. As seen from the XANES curves (Fig. 1f), the first inflection point on the edge corresponds to the E 0 values of In K-edge. Notably, the E 0 of In–O–C in In/G is higher than that of In–O in In2O3, indicating a higher oxidation state. Furthermore, the coordination environment of In was elucidated by EXAFS (Fig. 1g), which shows a notable peak at 1.4 Å for the In–O–C in In/G, closely resembling the In–O bond in In2O3 at 1.7 Å [39,40]. There is no peak corresponding to In–In coordination at 3.1 Å, which confirms the single atomic dispersion of indium bonded to oxygen in In/G. 2.2 Electrochemical performance of In/G electrode To validate the benefits of high-valence atomic In/G with an In-O-C configuration, In/G@Na||Na cells were assembled to evaluate the electrochemical stability of In/G electrode. The thickness of In/G and G coating layer on Cu foil is about 6.5 and 6.3 μm (Fig. S4), respectively. The 8 mAh cm−2 of Na is plated on the G (G@Na) and In/G electrodes (In/G@Na) at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 for 16 h. For comparison, the symmetrical cells composed of bare Na foil (Na||Na) are constructed. Fig. 2 (a) shows the voltage profiles of different electrodes cycled with a capacity of 1 mAh cm−2 at 8 mA cm−2, and Fig. S5 shows their enlarged voltage profiles for the intervals of 0–1, 34–35, and 159–160 h. It can be found that the Na||Na battery displays a very high initial overpotential of ∼180 mV and shows significant voltage fluctuation during the cycles, which is caused by repeated SEI fracture/formation. Although the overpotential of G@Na||Na is slightly lower than that of In/G@Na||Na in the initial hours, it rapidly increases and exhibits obvious fluctuation in subsequent cycles due to the formation of Na dendrites and even dead Na, eventually leading to a short circuit. On the contrary, the In/G@Na||Na battery has excellent cycle stability without any fluctuations within 160 h. It is noteworthy that the atomic In on the graphene layer can intrinsically induce the uniform nucleation and growth of Na within the graphene intermediate layer, promoting consistent growth of Na and preventing the growth of dendrites, thereby contributing to uniform Na deposition. To highlight the importance of In single atoms, the rate performance of In/G@Na||Na cells was measured at various current densities for a duration of 1 h during both the Na stripping and plating processes across each cycle (Fig. 2b). The 12 mAh cm−2 of Na is plated on the In/G electrodes (In/G@Na) at a current density of 0.5 mA cm−2 for 24 h. Notably, the overpotentials of Na stripping/plating are 7, 10, 20, 40, 64, 80, and 110 mV at 0.5, 1, 2, 4, 6, 8, and 10 mA cm−2, respectively. When the current density reverts to 0.5 mA cm−2, the overpotential value is restored to 8 mV. Notably, In/G exhibited competitive cycling stability (areal capacity, current density, and cycle number) and extraordinary rate capability (maximum areal capacity and current density), compared to the recently reported results of Na metal anodes (Fig. S6 and Tables S1 and S2) [41–47]. Therefore, the excellent cycle stability and rate performance of the In/G@Na||Na cells prove that atomic In can effectively inhibit the growth of Na dendrites and eventually improve the stability of the Na metal anode. The CE of half cells is a crucial indicator to determine the lifespan of Na metal anode in actual batteries. To this end, the CE of G||Na and In/G||Na half cells at a current density of 1 mA cm−2 was evaluated. The overpotential is only 14 mV for In/G at 1 mA cm−2, much lower than that of G (27 mV) (Fig. 2c). It can thus be concluded that high sodiophilic atomic In helps overcome the heterogeneous nucleation barrier. Moreover, the average CE of In/G is as high as 99.4% during 100 cycles, in stark contrast to the unstable CE of G electrode (Fig. S7a). From the galvanostatic plating/stripping of Na on In/G||Na and G||Na electrodes at 1 mA cm−2 (Fig. S7b, c), it is clearly observed that the In/G electrode maintains a stable charge-discharge curve. However, the G electrode exhibits obvious voltage oscillations during the stripping process, with CE greater than 100%, suggestive of an unstable SEI layer and electrical disconnection caused by dendrites on the electrode surface [19]. Furthermore, when the current density is increased to 2 mA cm−2 (Fig. S8), the In/G can still maintain stable CE during 100 cycles of plating/stripping. Impressively, the In/G@Na electrode can still maintain stable CE during 100 cycles of plating/stripping at a large current density of 8 mA cm−2 (Fig. 2d). However, the CE of the G electrode shows severe fluctuations, indicative of dendrite formation and dead Na related issues, particularly at high current density. The corresponding galvanostatic plating/stripping curves of Na on In/G||Na electrodes at 8 mA cm−2 (Fig. S9) exhibit high stability. The Na deposition behaviors have been further evaluated through in situ optical microscopy (Fig. 3 a, b) [48,49]. As the deposition time increases, an obvious bulge was observed on the surface of the G electrode, indicative of the formation of sodium dendrite. In contrast, the flat morphology on the surface of In/G@Na electrode manifests that the In single atoms can facilitate the uniform nucleation and in-plane growth of sodium metal. Moreover, cross-section SEM images of Na deposition after plating 3 mAh cm−2 have been observed (Fig. 3c, d). The relatively uniform Na metal on the surface of In/G@Na electrode indicates that the In single atoms can substantially inhibit the growth of Na dendrites. In addition, Fig. S10 shows the top-view SEM images of Na deposition after plating 3 mAh cm−2 of Na at 0.5 mA cm−2. Obviously, the loose and porous structure of Na metal is observed from the surface of G@Na electrode, indicating that the deposited Na is uneven due to the isolated nucleation. Furthermore, the electrochemical impedance spectroscopies (EIS) of In/G||Na and G||Na half cells after different cycles has been examined to illustrate the evolution of electrode/electrolyte interfacial impedance (Fig. S11) [50,51]. It is indicated that the In/G||Na half cells maintain relatively low interfacial impedance during the cycling process, and the resistance shows little fluctuation with the increasing cycling time, demonstrating the formation of stable SEI on the surface of In/G. In contrast, the interfacial impedance of G electrode increases significantly after 100 cycles. Last but not least, the SEM images of metal anode after different cycles have been further provided (Fig. S12). After 50 cycles, the relatively flat surface of the In/G electrode indicates better performance compared to the residual sodium on the surface of the G electrode. To highlight the differences in electrochemical properties between the atomic-stated In and the crystalline-stated In2O3, we also designed In2O3 nanoparticles (10–20 nm) anchored on graphene ((InO/G) by regulating the amount of In(NO3)3 (Figs. S13 and S14). Fig. S15 shows the CE of InO/G||Na at a current density of 1 mA cm−2, clearly exhibiting unstable CE of InO/G electrode, which is possibly caused by the decomposition of SEI [19]. This evidence suggests that the atomic In is more effective in inhibiting the growth of Na dendrites compared to crystalline-stated In2O3 in InO/G. 2.3 First principles calculation of In/G for Na deposition To elucidate the underlying mechanism of the uniform Na deposition behavior on single-atom In/G, density functional theory (DFT) calculations were conducted to simulate the deposition behavior of Na on the electrode surfaces of In/G in comparison with G. The four adsorption sites (top site IG-1, hexa-ring site IG-2, pentacyclic site IG-3, and adjacent hexa-ring site IG-4) for the Na atom on the In/G are shown in Fig. 4 (a). The three adsorption sites on G are depicted in Fig. 4(b). The binding energies of a Na atom at these different adsorption sites are summarized in Fig. 4(c). Notably, the binding energies of Na atoms at the four In/G sites (IG-1–IG-4) are closely aligned, measuring to be −3.04, −3.00, −3.04, and −3.03 eV respectively, which allows Na deposition on its surface easily and non-orientationally. It is noteworthy that the G used in this study was prepared by reducing GO, which contains a certain amount of oxygen defects. Consequently, the binding energies induced by oxygen-containing graphene (vacancy site OG-1, hexa-ring site OG-2, and adjacent hexa-ring site OG-3) are much lower than those of In/G. Besides, it is found that the binding energies of Na atoms at different sites of oxygen-containing graphene vary greatly, in which the OG-1 site (−2.22 eV) is much larger than OG-2 and OG-3 sites (−1.52 and −1.47 eV). These large differences in binding energy would lead to heterogeneous nucleation and selective deposition of Na atoms on the surface, which ultimately results in dendrite growth (Fig. 4d). Further, Fig. S16(a–c) shows the structures of Na adsorption on three main crystal faces of In2O3, namely (222), (440), and (400). The calculated binding energies of Na atoms on these different crystal surfaces are −3.27 eV for IO(400), −4.09 eV for IO(222), and −5.73 eV for IO(440) (Fig. S16d), which are generally higher than those observed on In/G, suggesting that Na atoms tend to deposit preferentially on In2O3 crystals, resulting in the generation of Na dendrite. Therefore, DFT further validates our observation that the introduction of atomic In promotes uniform Na nucleation, plating, and growth on the electrode surface (Fig. 4e). 2.4 Electrochemical performance of NVP||In/G@Na full cells To demonstrate the practical application of the In/G electrode, the NVP||In/G@Na (or NVP||G@Na) full cells were assembled (Fig. 5 a), in which the carbon-coated NVP (Figs. S17 and S18) with flower-like morphology was used as the cathode and In/G loaded with 3 mAh cm−2 Na at 0.5 mA cm−2 (In/G@Na) served as the anode. For comparison, a cell utilizing bare Na and NVP was also constructed and is denoted as NVP||Na. The galvanostatic charge and discharge profiles of NVP||In/G@Na battery (Fig. 5b) characterized by a typical two-phase reaction mechanism [52,53] exhibit low polarization voltages of 0.06, 0.08, 0.13, 0.18, 0.28, 0.37, and 0.45 V at varying rates of 1, 2, 5, 10, 20, 30, and 40 C, respectively. Importantly, the NVP||In/G@Na battery shows excellent rate capability (Fig. 5c), which can maintain the specific capacity of 102, 75, and 61 mAh g−1 at 1, 10, and 40 C, respectively. The specific capacity can be well restored to 102 mAh g−1, when the rate was reduced back to 1 C. Remarkably, Ragone plot of NVP||In/G@Na battery (Fig. S19) displays a high energy density of 338 Wh kg−1 at 1 C and a high power density of 14593 W kg−1 at 40 C (based on the mass of NVP), holding great promise for practical application. Furthermore, NVP||In/G@Na battery also shows outstanding cycling stability compared with NVP||G@Na (Fig. 5d and Fig. S20). NVP||In/G@Na battery offers a discharge capacity of 96 mAh g−1 after the 300th cycle, corresponding to a capacity retention of 93.8% and a low capacity decay rate of 0.021% per cycle. On the contrary, although the beginning capacities are similar, the capacity of NVP||G@Na cell drops sharply at less than 100 cycles, which may be caused by the formation of dendrites and the puncturing of the separator due to uneven deposition of Na. In addition, NVP||Na with large excess of Na anode also shows good cycling performance. In contrast, NVP||In/G@Na cell exhibits less voltage polarization, because In/G inhibits the growth of Na dendrites and enhances the electrochemical performance. To evaluate the electrochemical kinetics of NVP||In/G@Na battery, cyclic voltammetry (CV) curves at different scan rates were tested ranging from 0.1 to 2 mV s−1 within 2.5–3.8 V (Fig. 5e). The polarization of NVP||In/G@Na battery is as small as 0.15 V at a scan rate of 0.1 mV s−1, with a pair of cathodic/anodic peaks located at ∼3.32/3.47 V, demonstrative of excellent ion migration performance. Further, it is observed that the movement of the cathodic/anodic peaks was minimal, with shifts of only 0.12–0.15 V as the scan rate increases from 0.1 to 2 mV s−1. This is also supported by the high diffusion coefficient of Na ions ( D N a + ), calculated to be 6.62 × 10−11 and 4.05 × 10−11 cm2 s−1 (Fig. 5f). The current (i) and the scan rate (ν) obeys the power law (i = aνb , where a and b are adjustable parameters) [54]. The reaction kinetics is faster when the b value approaches 1. As shown in Fig. 5(g), the b values of peak 1 (b 1) and peak 2 (b 2) are calculated to be 0.60 and 0.65, respectively, according to the linear fitting plots of log(i p) vs. log(ν). All these observations clearly evidence the excellent kinetics of NVP||In/G@Na battery. 3 Conclusions In summary, we developed the single-atom In/G as exceptionally stable and dendrite-free anodes for high-energy-density SMBs. The introduction of atomic In promotes uniform Na nucleation on the electrode surface, eliminating preferential growth orientation. As a result, the Na dendrite growth is inhibited and the In/G||Na half batteries exhibit excellent long-cycle stability of 160 h at 8 mA cm−2, along with an ultralow overpotential of 110 mV at 10 mA cm−2. Furthermore, the NVP||In/G@Na batteries exhibit high discharge capacity (102 mAh g−1 at 1 C) and impressive rate performance (61 mAh g−1 at 40 C). Therefore, In/G-based Na metal anode offers all-round high performance, opening new avenues for the development of next-generation SMBs with high energy density. coredata.dc:description: Na metal batteries (SMBs) have emerged as a fascinating choice for large-scale energy storage. However, dendrite formation on Na metal anode has been acknowledged to cause inferior cycling stability and safety issues. Herein, we report the design of atomic indium-decorated graphene (In/G) to inhibit the growth of Na dendrites and substantially improve the stability of high-energy-density SMBs. Benefiting from the high-valence In-O-C configuration and evenly distributed sodiophilic sites, the In/G promotes uniform nucleation and in-plane growth of Na on the electrode surface, resulting in the intrinsic suppression of Na dendrites. Remarkably, the In/G@Na||Na batteries exhibit excellent long-term cyclability with 160 h at 8 mA cm−2 and ultralow overpotential of 110 mV at 10 mA cm−2. The Na3V2(PO4)3||In/G@Na full batteries show exceptionally high reversible discharge capacity of 61 mAh g−1 at an ultrahigh rate of 40 C and extremely low capacity decay rate of only 0.021% per cycle over 300 cycles at 1 C. Therefore, this strategy provides a new direction for the development of next-generation high-energy-density SMBs.

coredata.dc:title: Atomic indium decorated graphene for dendrite-free sodium anodes towards high-energy-density sodium-metal batteries
